node.name: Range
node.author: David Epstein
node.description: David Epstein examines how one should proceed with one's career, be it specialization or generalization. He goes into kind learning environments, unkind environments, the difference between the two, and the impact of far transfer.
node.value: Creative interdisciplinary work is the future.

node.name: Zero To One
node.author: Peter Thiel and Blake Masters
node.description: Thiel explains his outlook on life, what he looks for in a successful startup, and how you can take your startup from 0 to 1.
node.value: Contrarianism, Understanding tribalism, startup building. Master's online notes are better though.

node.name: The Mom Test
node.author: Rob Fitzpatrick
node.description: Rob explains how to gather user feedback, determine what users want, and avoid preference falsification without falling into the traditional pitfalls of self-validation.
node.value: How to understand people and their problems.

node.name: The Black Swan
node.author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
node.description: Taleb explains how we have this misguided notion of the bell curve, and how actually outlier events tend to define the narrative vis a vis fat-tailed distributions.

node.name: Deep Work
node.author: Cal Newport
node.description: Newport explains how society is progressing and the phenomenon of deep work. Instead of pretending to be busy or being consistently distracted and interrupted, Newport creates a schedule to optimize unconscious thought and flow.

node.name: Manufacturing Consent
node.author: Noam Chomsky and Edward Herman
node.description: Chomsky and Herman explore how the media is entangled with power and not necessarily in a good way. They explore how the Overton window gets set and what method and reasoning is used to prevent change to the status quo.

node.name: A Tree Grows In Brooklyn
node.author: Betty Smith
node.description: Smith details the world of a young girl, her childhood in Brooklyn, and her continued resilience in the face of adversity.

node.name: The Dream Machine: J.C.R. Licklider and the Revolution That Made Computing Personal
node.author: M. Mitchell Waldrop
